frontMatter.description: Learn about the integrated raft storage in Vault.

information. As of Vault 1.4 an integrated storage option is offered. This
storage backend does not rely on any third party systems, implements high
availability semantics, supports Enterprise Replication features, and provides
backup/restore workflows.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`The integrated storage option stores Vault's data on the server's filesystem and

`,mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"/docs/internals/integrated-storage/"}),`integrated storage internals
documentation`),`. Additionally, the

to the active Vault node.`),mdx("h3",e({},{className:"g-type-display-4"}),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h3"},{className:"__permalink-h",href:"#joining-nodes","aria-label":"joining nodes permalink"}),"\xBB"),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h3"},{className:"__target-h",id:"joining-nodes","aria-hidden":""})),"Joining Nodes"),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`Joining is the process of taking an uninitialized Vault node and making it a
member of an existing cluster. In order to authenticate the new node to the
cluster it must use the same seal mechanism. If using a Auto Unseal the node
must be configured to use the same KMS provider and Key as the cluster it's
attempting to join. If using a Shamir seal the unseal keys must be provided to
the new node before the join process can complete. Once a node has successfully
joined, data from the active node can begin to replicate to it. Once a node has
been joined it cannot be re-joined to a different cluster.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`You can either join the node automatically via the config file or manually through the

recommend setting the `,mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"/docs/concepts/ha#direct-access"}),"api_addr"),` configuration
option on all nodes to make joining simpler.`),mdx("h4",e({},{className:"g-type-display-5"}),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h4"},{className:"__permalink-h",href:"#retry_join-configuration","aria-label":"retry_join configuration permalink"}),"\xBB"),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h4"},{className:"__target-h",id:"retry_join-configuration","aria-hidden":""})),"retry_join Configuration"),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`This method enables setting one, or more, target leader nodes in the config file.

the joined nodes will still need to be unsealed manually. When using Auto Unseal
the node will be able to join and unseal automatically.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),"An example ",mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"/docs/configuration/storage/raft#retry_join-stanza"}),"retry_join"),`

This is used by Vault
nodes to issue RPCs to one another, e.g. to forward requests from a standby node
to the active node, or when Raft is in use, to handle leader election and
replication of stored data.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`The cluster port is secured using a TLS certificate that the Vault active node
generates internally.  It's clear how this can work when not using integrated
storage: every node has at least read access to storage, so once the active
node has persisted the certificate, the standby nodes can fetch it, and all
agree on how cluster traffic should be encrypted.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`It's less clear how this works with integrated storage, as there is a chicken
and egg problem.  Nodes don't have a shared view of storage until the raft
cluster has been formed, but we're trying to form the raft cluster!  To solve
this problem, a Vault node must speak to another Vault node using the API port
instead of the cluster port.  This is currently the only situation in which
OSS Vault does this (Vault Enterprise also does something similar when setting
up replication.)`),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",e({parentName:"ul"},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),"node2 wants to join the cluster, so issues challenge API request to existing member node1"),mdx("li",e({parentName:"ul"},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),"node1 replies to challenge request with (1) an encrypted random UUID and (2) seal config"),mdx("li",e({parentName:"ul"},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),"node2 must decrypt UUID using seal; if using auto-unseal can do it directly, if using shamir must wait for user to provide enough unseal keys to perform decryption"),mdx("li",e({parentName:"ul"},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),"node2 sends decrypted UUID back to node1 using answer API"),mdx("li",e({parentName:"ul"},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),"node1 sees node2 can be trusted (since it has seal access) and replies with a bootstrap package which includes the cluster TLS certificate and private key"),mdx("li",e({parentName:"ul"},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),"node2 gets sent a raft snapshot over the cluster port")),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`After this procedure the new node will never again send traffic to the API port.

it may be a pain.  For similar reasons this solution may be impractical when
using non-voting nodes and dynamically scaling clusters.`),mdx("h4",e({},{className:"g-type-display-5"}),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h4"},{className:"__permalink-h",href:"#load-balancer-instead-of-autojoin","aria-label":"load balancer instead of autojoin permalink"}),"\xBB"),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h4"},{className:"__target-h",id:"load-balancer-instead-of-autojoin","aria-hidden":""})),"Load balancer instead of autojoin"),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`Most Vault instances are going to have a load balancer (LB) between clients and
the Vault nodes.  In that case, the LB knows how to route traffic to working
Vault nodes, and there's no need for auto-join: we can just use retry_join
with the LB address as the target.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`One potential issue here: some users want a public facing LB for clients to
connect to Vault, but aren't comfortable with Vault internal traffic
egressing from the internal network it normally runs on.`),mdx("h2",e({},{className:"g-type-display-3"}),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h2"},{className:"__permalink-h",href:"#outage-recovery","aria-label":"outage recovery permalink"}),"\xBB"),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h2"},{className:"__target-h",id:"outage-recovery","aria-hidden":""})),"Outage Recovery"),mdx("h3",e({},{className:"g-type-display-4"}),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h3"},{className:"__permalink-h",href:"#quorum-maintained","aria-label":"quorum maintained permalink"}),"\xBB"),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h3"},{className:"__target-h",id:"quorum-maintained","aria-hidden":""})),"Quorum Maintained"),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`This section outlines the steps to take when a single server or multiple servers
are in a failed state but quorum is still maintained. This means the remaining
alive servers are still operational, can elect a leader, and are able to process
write requests.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`If the failed server is recoverable, the best option is to bring it back online
and have it reconnect to the cluster with the same host address. This will return
the cluster to a fully healthy state.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`If this is impractical, you need to remove the failed server. Usually, you can
issue a remove-peer command to remove the failed server if it's still a member
of the cluster.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`If the remove-peer command isn't possible or you'd rather manually re-write the
cluster membership a `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"raft/peers.json"),` file can be written to the configured
data directory.`),mdx("h3",e({},{className:"g-type-display-4"}),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h3"},{className:"__permalink-h",href:"#quorum-lost","aria-label":"quorum lost permalink"}),"\xBB"),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h3"},{className:"__target-h",id:"quorum-lost","aria-hidden":""})),"Quorum Lost"),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`In the event that multiple servers are lost, causing a loss of quorum and a
complete outage, partial recovery is still possible.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`If the failed servers are recoverable, the best option is to bring them back
online and have them reconnect to the cluster using the same host addresses.
This will return the cluster to a fully healthy state.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`If the failed servers are not recoverable, partial recovery is possible using
data on the remaining servers in the cluster. There may be data loss in this
situation because multiple servers were lost, so information about what's
committed could be incomplete. The recovery process implicitly commits all
outstanding Raft log entries, so it's also possible to commit data that was
uncommitted before the failure.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`See the section below on manual recovery using peers.json for details of the
recovery procedure. You include only the remaining servers in the
raft/peers.json recovery file. The cluster should be able to elect a leader once
the remaining servers are all restarted with an identical raft/peers.json
configuration.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`Any servers you introduce later can be fresh with totally clean data
directories and joined using Vault's join command.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`In extreme cases, it should be possible to recover with just a single remaining
server by starting that single server with itself as the only peer in the
raft/peers.json recovery file.`),mdx("h3",e({},{className:"g-type-display-4"}),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h3"},{className:"__permalink-h",href:"#manual-recovery-using-peers-json","aria-label":"manual recovery using peers json permalink"}),"\xBB"),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h3"},{className:"__target-h",id:"manual-recovery-using-peers-json","aria-hidden":""})),"Manual Recovery Using peers.json"),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),`Using raft/peers.json for recovery can cause uncommitted Raft log entries to be

option is available to recover a lost server. Make sure you don't have any
automated processes that will put the peers file in place on a periodic basis.`),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),"To begin, stop all remaining servers."),mdx("p",e({},{className:"g-type-long-body"}),"The next step is to go to the ",mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"/docs/configuration/storage/raft/#path"}),`configured data
path`),` of each Vault server. Inside that
directory, there will be a raft/ sub-directory. We need to create a
raft/peers.json file. The file should be formatted as a JSON array containing
the node ID, address:port, and suffrage information of each Vault server you
wish to be in the cluster.`),mdx("pre",e({},{className:"language-json"}),mdx("code",e({parentName:"pre"},{className:"language-json"}),mdx("span",e({parentName:"code"},{className:"token punctuation"}),"["),`
